clusters.title: How modern life makes us sick – and what to do about it
clusters.neutral_headline: How modern life makes us sick, and what to do

items.title: How modern life makes us sick – and what to do about it
items.standfirst: From depression to obesity, the concept of ‘evolutionary mismatch’ can help foster self-compassion and point the way to a more rewarding existenceOne of the fascinating things about working as a psychotherapist is the opportunity to observe how many of our problems involve us getting in the way of ourselves. The difficulties we encounter are frequently the result of self-sabotage, and managing them often requires wrestling with our own drives, doing our best not to give in to every impulse. This is easier said than done, of course. To lose weight and keep it off, to successfully climb out of debt, to find meaningful work, to maintain long-term, happy relationships: all demand postponing our immediate desires in the service of a longer-term goal.Delaying gratification, as it’s called, has been a useful tactic for aeons. But at a certain point it becomes reasonable to ask: why does so much of modern life seem to involve swimming upstream? Why is it that following our instincts often seems to land us in so much trouble? Continue reading...
items.content: From depression to obesity, the concept of ‘evolutionary mismatch’ can help foster self-compassion and point the way to a more rewarding existenceOne of the fascinating things about working as a psychotherapist is the opportunity to observe how many of our problems involve us getting in the way of ourselves. The difficulties we encounter are frequently the result of self-sabotage, and managing them often requires wrestling with our own drives, doing our best not to give in to every impulse. This is easier said than done, of course. To lose weight and keep it off, to successfully climb out of debt, to find meaningful work, to maintain long-term, happy relationships: all demand postponing our immediate desires in the service of a longer-term goal.Delaying gratification, as it’s called, has been a useful tactic for aeons. But at a certain point it becomes reasonable to ask: why does so much of modern life seem to involve swimming upstream? Why is it that following our instincts often seems to land us in so much trouble? Continue reading...

ai_summary: Modern life can contribute to various health problems.
The concept of "evolutionary mismatch" is discussed.
The article suggests self-compassion as a solution.
The article explores the challenges of modern living.
The article offers insights into improving well-being.

clusters.title: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic
clusters.neutral_headline: I struggled with infertility, then had a life-changing call

items.title: For years I struggled with infertility and loss. Then I had a life-changing call with a psychic
items.standfirst: On some level, I realised it was a bit unhinged, writes the author and podcaster Elizabeth Day. But what did I have to lose? On 29 December 2022, I received a text. ‘Hi mum I’m texting you off a friends phone I’ve smashed mine and their phones about to die, can you WhatsApp my new number x’ I was in a rental car when I got it, my partner at the wheel next to me as we drove down an anonymous stretch of motorway. Both the sky and the road were grey. It was that indeterminate space between Christmas and New Year when the days become sludgy and diffuse; a time when teenagers meet up with their friends to go shopping or gather in each other’s homes and post Snapchats or exchange festive gossip while pretending not to vape. It was the time of waiting – for the next thing to happen, for the promised excitement of New Year’s Eve and snogging underneath leftover mistletoe. So it wasn’t a particularly unusual text to receive, especially not given the trademark adolescent lack of grammar and punctuation.There was just one thing. Continue reading...
items.content: On some level, I realised it was a bit unhinged, writes the author and podcaster Elizabeth Day. But what did I have to lose? On 29 December 2022, I received a text. ‘Hi mum I’m texting you off a friends phone I’ve smashed mine and their phones about to die, can you WhatsApp my new number x’ I was in a rental car when I got it, my partner at the wheel next to me as we drove down an anonymous stretch of motorway. Both the sky and the road were grey. It was that indeterminate space between Christmas and New Year when the days become sludgy and diffuse; a time when teenagers meet up with their friends to go shopping or gather in each other’s homes and post Snapchats or exchange festive gossip while pretending not to vape. It was the time of waiting – for the next thing to happen, for the promised excitement of New Year’s Eve and snogging underneath leftover mistletoe. So it wasn’t a particularly unusual text to receive, especially not given the trademark adolescent lack of grammar and punctuation.There was just one thing. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author discusses struggles with infertility and loss.
The author received a life-changing call from a psychic.
The author reflects on the experience and its impact.

The author shares a personal and emotional story.

clusters.title: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t
clusters.neutral_headline: Stroke during ocean swim, most people unaware

items.title: I had a stroke during an ocean swim. Most people passed by unaware. One didn’t
items.standfirst: When Graham Russell set out for a dip in powerful wintry surf, he had no idea the beach where he had helped save lives as a surf lifesaver would become the place where his own was changedIt was an exhilarating day in every possible way. Standing on the cold sand on a Sunday morning, I saw the sun flash off powerful surf as it curved into whitewater that rushed up the beach. The sound of it boomed around the nearby cliffs. The passing clouds threw dark green patches across the frothy water, the air was crisp and dry. Today’s swim promised to be great.The members of my winter swimming club were pulling on cozzies, bright pink swimming caps and goggles as they assessed the challenging conditions. The car park was jammed with surfers from all around. Word had spread that MacMasters beach here on the New South Wales Central Coast was the place to experience this monstrous east swell.Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads Continue reading...
items.content: When Graham Russell set out for a dip in powerful wintry surf, he had no idea the beach where he had helped save lives as a surf lifesaver would become the place where his own was changedIt was an exhilarating day in every possible way. Standing on the cold sand on a Sunday morning, I saw the sun flash off powerful surf as it curved into whitewater that rushed up the beach. The sound of it boomed around the nearby cliffs. The passing clouds threw dark green patches across the frothy water, the air was crisp and dry. Today’s swim promised to be great.The members of my winter swimming club were pulling on cozzies, bright pink swimming caps and goggles as they assessed the challenging conditions. The car park was jammed with surfers from all around. Word had spread that MacMasters beach here on the New South Wales Central Coast was the place to experience this monstrous east swell.Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads Continue reading...

The event changed the author's life.
The article describes a dramatic personal experience.

clusters.title: Labour’s NHS job cuts plan in chaos amid row over £1bn costs
clusters.neutral_headline: Labour's NHS job cuts plan in chaos amid cost row

items.title: Labour’s NHS job cuts plan in chaos amid row over £1bn costs
items.standfirst: Integrated care boards in England cannot afford severance payments, leaving restructuring plan in chaos, union saysLabour’s radical reorganisation of the NHS has descended into chaos, a union has said, as a huge programme of job cuts has been halted amid a row over who will foot the £1bn bill.The NHS’s 42 integrated care boards (ICBs) in England were due to make up to 12,500 of their 25,000 staff redundant by the end of the year as a result of health service cost-cutting. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Labour's NHS job cuts plan is in chaos.
A union says the plan is halted due to costs.
Integrated care boards cannot afford severance.
The plan involves cutting up to 12,500 jobs.
The plan is part of health service cost-cutting.

clusters.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel votes against recommending prescription for Covid vaccine, emphasizing personal choice
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel votes against recommending prescription for Covid vaccine, emphasizing personal choice

items.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel votes against recommending prescription for Covid vaccine, emphasizing personal choice
items.standfirst: After heated meeting, healthcare professionals and experts left deeply confused about committee’s recommendationsA powerful committee that advises the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on vaccine policy voted on Friday against recommending that people obtain a prescription for a Covid-19 vaccine. However, the panel also voted to recommend that people speak with a clinician before obtaining the shot and that coronavirus vaccinations should be based on “individual-based decision making”.The votes on the recommendations came after hours of impassioned debate that, at times, devolved into confusion and apparent animosity over the committee’s procedures and the safety of vaccines. Healthcare professionals and experts following the committee’s meeting were also left deeply confused about the significance of the committee’s votes and recommendations, and whether they would make it more difficult for people to obtain Covid vaccines. Continue reading...
items.content: After heated meeting, healthcare professionals and experts left deeply confused about committee’s recommendationsA powerful committee that advises the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on vaccine policy voted on Friday against recommending that people obtain a prescription for a Covid-19 vaccine. However, the panel also voted to recommend that people speak with a clinician before obtaining the shot and that coronavirus vaccinations should be based on “individual-based decision making”.The votes on the recommendations came after hours of impassioned debate that, at times, devolved into confusion and apparent animosity over the committee’s procedures and the safety of vaccines. Healthcare professionals and experts following the committee’s meeting were also left deeply confused about the significance of the committee’s votes and recommendations, and whether they would make it more difficult for people to obtain Covid vaccines. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A vaccine panel voted against recommending a prescription.
The panel emphasized individual-based decision making.
The panel recommended speaking with a clinician first.
The vote followed hours of debate and confusion.
The panel advises the CDC on vaccine policy.

clusters.title: The pill, Puerto Rico and the patriarchal medical system | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Contraception Attitudes and Medical Misogyny Explored in Research

items.title: The pill, Puerto Rico and the patriarchal medical system | Letters
items.standfirst: Rebecca Siddall responds to an article on attitudes to the contraceptive pill and reflects on medical misogynyYour article on contraception misinformation does not consider the long history of medical misogyny (Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds, 13 September). I am a PhD researcher studying the cultural discourse on contraception. I’m also a young woman within the age range and online culture that you talk about, and within my work I explore this space critically.Effectively, it is wrong to assume a value-neutral background when researching attitudes to contraception, a medical technology that is only available to us now through historical injustices enacted upon women, especially women of colour. Continue reading...
items.content: Rebecca Siddall responds to an article on attitudes to the contraceptive pill and reflects on medical misogynyYour article on contraception misinformation does not consider the long history of medical misogyny (Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds, 13 September). I am a PhD researcher studying the cultural discourse on contraception. I’m also a young woman within the age range and online culture that you talk about, and within my work I explore this space critically.Effectively, it is wrong to assume a value-neutral background when researching attitudes to contraception, a medical technology that is only available to us now through historical injustices enacted upon women, especially women of colour. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A PhD researcher studies cultural discourse on contraception, including online attitudes.
The researcher is a young woman within the age range and online culture discussed.
Research should not assume a value-neutral background when studying contraception.
Historical injustices against women, especially women of color, are relevant.
Contraception is a medical technology available due to historical injustices.

clusters.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel drops plan for vote on newborn hepatitis B shots
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr's Vaccine Panel Delays Vote on Newborn Hepatitis B Shots

items.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel drops plan for vote on newborn hepatitis B shots
items.standfirst: Committee cited inconsistency in proposed policy changes and it is not clear how they will proceed on the issueA revamped panel of US vaccine advisers appointed by the health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, on Friday decided not to go ahead with a planned vote that would have delayed the first hepatitis B vaccine dose for newborns, citing inconsistency in the proposed policy changes.It was not clear how the committee would now proceed on the issue. Continue reading...
items.content: Committee cited inconsistency in proposed policy changes and it is not clear how they will proceed on the issueA revamped panel of US vaccine advisers appointed by the health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, on Friday decided not to go ahead with a planned vote that would have delayed the first hepatitis B vaccine dose for newborns, citing inconsistency in the proposed policy changes.It was not clear how the committee would now proceed on the issue. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A US vaccine advisory panel delayed a vote on delaying the first hepatitis B vaccine dose.
The panel cited inconsistency in proposed policy changes as the reason for the delay.
The panel was appointed by the health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr.
It is unclear how the committee will proceed on the issue of newborn hepatitis B shots.
The panel's decision was made on Friday.

clusters.title: More kissing, less kimchi: seven surprising ways to boost your gut health
clusters.neutral_headline: Diverse Methods to Improve Gut Health Beyond Diet

items.title: More kissing, less kimchi: seven surprising ways to boost your gut health
items.standfirst: From gardening and humming to getting a dog – there’s more to boosting your gut microbiome than Greek yogurtWhen the gut health revolution began a decade or so ago, few could have predicted the sheer variety of pre- and probiotic foods that we would come to embrace in our diets. From kimchi and natural yoghurt to fibre-rich jerusalem artichoke and probiotic shots, microbiome-nourishing foods and supplements once deemed left-field have become everyday essentials for many – with plenty of evidence that they help our gut bacteria to thrive.While many of us assume that diet is the only way to feed the trillions of microorganisms (including bacteria, fungi and viruses) that make up the microbiome, there are myriad daily habits that can help nurture this important part of the body. Continue reading...
items.content: From gardening and humming to getting a dog – there’s more to boosting your gut microbiome than Greek yogurtWhen the gut health revolution began a decade or so ago, few could have predicted the sheer variety of pre- and probiotic foods that we would come to embrace in our diets. From kimchi and natural yoghurt to fibre-rich jerusalem artichoke and probiotic shots, microbiome-nourishing foods and supplements once deemed left-field have become everyday essentials for many – with plenty of evidence that they help our gut bacteria to thrive.While many of us assume that diet is the only way to feed the trillions of microorganisms (including bacteria, fungi and viruses) that make up the microbiome, there are myriad daily habits that can help nurture this important part of the body. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses ways to boost gut health beyond just diet.

Examples include kimchi, yogurt, fiber-rich foods, and probiotic supplements.
Daily habits like gardening and humming can also nurture the microbiome.
The article suggests getting a dog can also help improve gut health.
